.@Need2Impeach is just getting started. We’ll be holding town halls nationwide, organizing a summit in DC, launching a public ed initiative on Mr. Trump’s impeachable offenses and the impeachment process, and pressuring lawmakers to take a stand. Join us. https://t.co/NE6lsK1R0e

I will do whatever it takes, for as long as it takes, to remove this president.

Not because I disagree with his policies. Not because we hold different ideologies. 

But because the right time to do the right thing is ALWAYS right now.

Some continue to argue that holding this president accountable for his illegal, immoral behavior would be too divisive. They are avoiding the truth: Mr. Trump has made division the centerpiece of his presidency. That’s why he must go.

In 2018, I committed to flipping the House. In 2019, I’m committed to seeing the House impeach this president. We must begin impeachment proceedings, or Mr. Trump must resign. That’s how we’ll define success this year.

The impeachment question has reached an inflection point. That’s why I just announced that I will be dedicating 100% of my time and effort in 2019 towards Mr. Trump’s impeachment and removal from office.
I’m about to hold a press conference detailing my plans for this year and beyond, and I want you to hear about them. Stay tuned for updates.

That's why I'm fighting not just to impeach and remove this president, but for the 5 Rights: A framework for civil society would lead to economic stability for all. That's something all Americans—and millennials, in particular—would benefit. (9/9)

They want candidates who'll prove they understand their struggles—student debt, job insecurity, costly health care, to name a few—& are ready to fight for real solutions. Talk just won't do it anymore. Young people deserve leaders who will make our democracy function again. (8/9)

2018 disproved the cliched narrative that millennials are “lazy.” The truth is, they’re hungry. They got a small taste of their potential in our politics last year. In 2020, they’ll be coming out for more. (7/9)

And we weren’t the only ones rallying these voters in 2018. Across the country, organizations like @AMarch4OurLives and others got young people to stand up and speak out. Without these voters, Democrats would not have a House majority today. (6/9)

We even mobilized voters to send millennials like Abby Finkenauer, Katie Hill, Josh Harder, and Chris Pappas to Washington. Their voices will ensure young people are represented in our politics. (5/9)
Our work was decisive in Jacky Rosen, Steve Sisolak, and Debbie Mucarsel-Powell’s races. The voters we engaged pushed those candidates to victory. (4/9)

In virtually every precinct we tracked, young voter turnout exceeded 2014 levels. In some instances, we doubled—or even tripled—turnout over the previous midterm elections. https://t.co/EXiPeZ1xv0 (3/9)

@NextGenAmerica was a millennial mobilization machine in ’18, made up of 700 staffers and over 16,000 volunteers, spreading a powerful message to young people in 11 states: voting is the first step to change. Those young people listened, and rose to the occasion. (2/9)

Donald Trump is selling out working America for his own profit, and the profit of his millionaire cronies.

Or Steve Mnuchin, Trump’s millionaire Treasury Secretary & former Goldman Sachs exec who requested a taxpayer-funded jet for his honeymoon.
Rich people like Donald Trump, the first president in decades who refuses to release his tax returns. How much would he profit from this?
Instead, Republicans want to cut taxes for the rich, because they want the rich to have more money.
And, they wouldn’t push a plan that gives tax breaks to corporations that ship jobs overseas.
They wouldn't threaten programs like Medicare, Social Security, and public education that strengthen the middle class.
If Republicans really wanted to help people, they’d make healthcare more affordable, not less. They’d be tough on polluters, not unions.
Doesn’t happen. You know it. I know it. They know it. We all know it.

Republicans know that if they say “We want to give rich people all the money because we like them better” they won’t get far.
Republicans in Washington know this, of course.
The richest 1% now take 20% of all income and hold nearly 40% of all wealth in America, and everyone else struggles to get by.
Income inequality skyrocketed. Middle-class wages stagnated. The share of all income taken by the richest 1% has doubled.
Starting with Reagan, we cut the top tax rate on the richest Americans from 70% to 39%. The Rich got richer, everyone else got screwed.
Republicans say if we cut taxes for rich people the benefits will trickle down to everyone else. Hasn’t worked for 40 years, won’t work now.
They’re lying about what it would do, and they’re lying about why they want to do it.
The first thing you need to understand about the Trump/Republican tax plan is that they’re lying about it.
